>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
> > Every activation returns ONE pixel.  Which pixel, and how big that
>pixel is
> > is determined by the top,left,right,bottom inputs.  a top,left of
>0,0 and
>
>Do you mean outputs rather than inputs?  This description doesn't
>seem to leave anything left for the network to decide if everything
>is based on only its inputs?

No, I mean inputs.  What's being asked of the network is for it to form a 
model of its pixel inputs, and then use the top,left,bottom,right inputs to 
specify which part of that model we are interested in.  So if the pixel 
inputs indicate a smooth gradient from upper left to lower right, the model 
should reflect that.  Then, if I ask it for the center portion of the model, 
it should return a value that is the average intensity of that region of the 
model.

The problem I have is the evolutionary pressure I'm applying.  When I was 
asking it to do the 'reduction' first, that created a pressure that forced 
it to optimize towards simply averaging its inputs.  That doesn't do me any 
good.  When I do ALL activations, there's still a majority of activations 
that are just verifying its ability to do reductions.  So it can still 
optimize itself into uselessness...  BUT...if I turn it around and ask it to 
do enlargements first and only reductions if it succeeds at enlargements, 
then the pressure to actually evolve what I was looking for is much 
stronger.  MUCH stronger.  Then, once it has evolved that, everything else 
is just optimization and error-reduction.

I'm going to give that a try.  I'm going to restart the experiment (again) 
as soon as the machine is done making the smaller versions of the original 
images.
